details.title: An optimal designed degradation experiment for reliability improvement
details.standardTitle: An optimal designed degradation experiment for reliability improvement

p: Hong-Fwu Yu is an Associate Professor in the Department of Industrial Management at National Huwei Institute of Technology. His research interests include data-analysis and experimental-design of (accelerated) degradation tests.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Manage., Nat. Huwei Inst. of Technol., Yunlin, Taiwan
authors.name: Hong-Fwu Yu

p: Chih-Hua Chiao is a Professor in the Department of Business Mathematics at Soochow University. His research interests include accelerated life tests, degradation data and reliability improvement. He received a Ph.D. in 1993 in industrial management from the National Taiwan Institute of Technology.

details.abstract: In conducting a design-of-experiments, with degradation data, to improve the reliability of highly reliable products, one of the most important topics for manufacturers is to identify important factors that affect the product reliability. Several decision variables such as inspection frequency, sample size, and termination time at each run, do influence the precision of identifying the important factors and the experimental cost. This paper proposes a systematic approach to the identification problem with respect to fractional factorial degradation experiments. First, an intuitively appealing identification rule is proposed. Next, the optimum test plan is derived using the criterion of minimizing the total experimental cost. The inspection frequency, sample size, and termination time at each run, that are needed by this identification rule are computed by solving a nonlinear integer programming model with a minimum probability of correct selection. A simulation study investigates the efficiency of this method.

context.text: Reference [1]addresses the problem of designing a class of ADT.

Under the constraints that the life-testing time is pre-determined and the total number of measurement-times is fixed and known, [1]discusses issues such as the times to measure the devices, and the number of devices to test at each stress level.

context.text: Reference [13] introduces a case study on how a designed degradation experiment is used to identify important factors and then improve the reliability of fluorescent lamps.
To improve the reliability of fluorescent lamps, [13] conducts a 2(3-1) fractional factorial experiment to study 3 2-level factors in 4 different combinations of factor levels.
Because the 95% CI of the difference of 2 main effects of Factors 2 and 3 do not contain 0, [13] concludes that \$F_2\$ and \$F_3\$ are important.
Section V uses the designed experiment of fluorescent lamps in [13] to illustrate this algorithm.
Reference [13] estimated them as:The 95% CI of \$\{\theta_h\}_{h=1}^3\$ are:According to these results, [13] concludes that \$F_2\$ and \$F_3\$ are important.

Thus, if the true configuration of \$(\mu_1,\, \mu_2,\, \mu_3,\, \mu_4) , \ (\sigma^2,\, \sigma_{\epsilon}^2)\$ is \$(\hat{\mu}_1,\, \hat{\mu}_2,\, \hat{\mu}_3,\, \hat{\mu}_4) , \ (\hat{\sigma}^2,\, \hat{\sigma}_{\epsilon}^2)\$ in [13], then there is at least 90% \$s\$-confidence in covering each factor correctly.
For comparison, regard the inspections for runs 1–4 of the designed degradation experiment in [13] to be taken up to 6 k, 12 k, 6 k, and 12 k hours at 1 k hours interval, respectively.
That is,Based on the settings of \$C_s , \ C_{\rm op} , \ C_m\$, and \$C_d\$, the expense in [13] is \$2973.

links.abstract: Analysis of degradation data can provide information about the lifetime of highly reliable products, if there exists a product characteristic whose degradation over time can be related to reliability. To obtain a precise estimator of a product mean time-to-failure, one practical problem arising from designing a degradation experiment is: how long should the experiment last? This paper proposes a termination rule to determine an appropriate stopping time of a degradation experiment. A case study ...

context.text: Reference [14] proposes an intuitively on-line and real-time rule to determine an appropriate termination time for a degradation experiment.

references.title: A termination rule for degradation experiments
references.text: S. T. Tseng, H. F. Yu, "A termination rule for degradation experiments", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 46, pp. 130-133, 1997.

context.text: Reference [15] clearly describes the relationship between these decision variables and some other issues (e.g., the product's degradation rate, measurement errors, and a variety of conducting costs) for a degradation experiment.

Under the constraint that the total cost of the experiment does not exceed a pre-determined budget, [15] determines the optimal combination of these 3 decision variables by minimizing the variance of the estimated 100 pth percentile of the lifetime distribution of the product.
Also [15]uses \$\phi(x)= \log(x)\$ with \$\alpha=0.5\$ to describe the degradation paths for an LED product.

For \$1 \leq j \leq n , \ 1 \leq i \leq r\$, based on the observations the LSE \$\hat{\beta}_{i,\,j}\$ of \$\beta_{i,\,j}\$, conditioned on \$\beta_{i,\,j}\$, can be computed by minimizing Thus,Let From [15], if \$\sum_{k=1}^{l_i}\,t_{i,\, k}^{2\alpha}\$ is sufficiently large, then \$\hat{\mu}_i\$ is an approximately unbiased estimator for \$\mu_i\$ with variance \$(1/n)\cdot \sigma^2_{\mu_i}\$, where\$\hat{\sigma}_i^{2}\$ is also an approximately unbiased estimator for \$\sigma^2\$.
From [15], if \$\sum_{k=1}^{l_i}\, t_{i,\, k}^{2\alpha}\$ is sufficiently large, the unconditional distribution of \$\log(\hat{\beta}_{i,\,j})\$ is approximately \$s\$-normal.

links.abstract: The reliability of high radiance InGaAsP/InP DH LED's operating in the<tex>1.2-1.3 \mu</tex>m wavelength and the defect structures observed in this quaternary alloy have been presented. Threading dislocations and misfit dislocations do not act as strong nonradiative recombination centers, in contrast with the case in GaAs or GaAlAs optical devices. Dark-spot defects (DSD's) were sometimes generated in the emitting area during aging at elevated temperatures. These defects were analyzed microscopi...
